Award.AwardTitle: Programmed Assembly of Conductive Protein Crystals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical: This award by the Biomaterials Program in the Division of Materials Research to Colorado State University is to design new materials by encoding the assembly of building block proteins. This award is cofunded by US Army Natick Soldier Research, Development & Engineering Center. The intended crystalline biomaterials are so precisely organized that they will diffract X-rays, allowing high-resolution determination of the molecular structure details. While there are many possible applications for such materials, this proposal focuses on (1) determining the extent to which the position of constituent building blocks can be programmed, and (2) assessing applications for the protein crystal pore network. Specifically, the project will produce and characterize close-packed hexagonal arrays of nanowires that may form useful ultra-high surface area materials for catalysis or battery applications. Porous protein crystals may also offer advantages as multifunctional delivery materials, combining high capacity with the possibility of extensive nanostructure control. The project provides educational opportunities from high school and the University due to integration with AP Chemistry and Biomolecular Engineering courses, as well as broad dissemination via an open-source software platform (SHARPEN) for protein modeling and design.

Technical: The proposed research will study proteins as building blocks to assemble crystalline materials in which it is possible to exert sub-nanometer control over the location of constituent domains. This research will also exploit the highly anisotropic pore structure of existing protein crystals in pursuit of nanostructured material applications. The project will produce and characterize close-packed hexagonal arrays of nanowires via synthesis of conductive polymers or the capture of carbon nanotubes within a parallel array of nanopores. Additionally, the research will determine the suitability of porous crystals to serve as depots for the controlled release of antimicrobial peptides under challenging operational conditions. Specifically, the project will assess the extent to which protein crystals with very different pore sizes adsorb antimicrobial peptides, conditionally gate guest peptide release, and withstand demanding conditions including denaturants, heat, freeze-thaw cycles, and desiccation. This proposal also includes a software engineering effort to improve accessibility of the SHARPEN platform, further extending the impact of protein design methodology improvements. Research training will encompass cutting-edge areas of bionanotechnology, molecular modeling, and nanostructure imaging.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scientific Impact. This grant played a central role in developing porous protein crystals as a new platform technology. Key results include:

A. The refinement of reliable methods for converting fragile protein crystals into robust, crosslinked, highly-ordered scaffold materials suitable for downstream applications. The resulting crystals are remarkably stable with respect to challenging solution conditions (Figure 1). A full technical description of the numerous crosslinking chemistry variations tested is in preparation for publication.

B. The development of methods for controlled loading and release of guest macromolecules from these crystals was published (Small). Functional guest enzymes were also been loaded. Specifically, we demonstrated that an enzyme pathway can function (Figure 2) inside of a host crystal. This work will shortly be published. We also pursued a quantitative understanding of guest macromolecule diffusion and adsorption inside the crystals (J. Phys. Chem. B). Finally, we determined that guest DNA is adsorbed with extraordinarily high affinity, a discovery that raises the possibility of DNA storage and protection applications.

C. The development of computational methods for designing new biomolecular crystal forms. The first of two planned computational crystal design papers was published (Crystal Growth and Design).

D. Designing new crystal forms was a challenging primary goal for this project. We started by redesigning the interface of our primary porous protein crystal and obtained high-resolution x-ray structures thereof. More dramatically, we recently obtained small crystals for biomolecular co-crystal variants that were designed to have altered solvent pore geometry (Figure 1).

E. We developed chemistry for incorporating electrically conductive materials into the solvent channels of protein crystals. Controlling the nucleation and growth of non-biological guest materials proved to be quite challenging. Nonetheless, we were able to characterize two conductive guest materials: polypyrrole and gold.

In sum, this grant contributed a critical scientific foundation of understanding for host-guest protein crystals as a material.

Technology Impact. In addition to the aforementioned scientific impact, this grant included a large focus on demonstrating the potential of engineered porous crystals for applications. The general idea was to provide proof of concept demonstrations or feasibility tests that highlight the unusual attributes of porous protein crystals as materials. In brief, materials that are composed entirely of proteins should enjoy certain advantages in terms of biocompatibility. Also, the crosslinked honeycomb topology of the crystal can be quite robust with respect to mechanical or solvent challenge. Finally, the close-packed array of 13-nm nanopores in the crystal (80% solvent) leads to a very high theoretical capacity for securely containing guest molecules.

A. As a practical consideration, we developed methods for reliably growing crystals with varying size and aspect ratio. The porous crystals can be grown with diameter of hundreds of nanometers up to 1 millimeter. The aspect ratio of these hexagonal prisms can be varied from thin plates to long rods.

B. To broaden the applications for engineered crystals, we developed methods to attach the crystals to larger materials. In particular, we elucidated chemistry to attach the crystals to cotton (and withstand laundering). These crystals can be subsequently loaded with functional enzymes (Figure 4). This work is in preparation for resubmission. This result opens the door for applications related to multifunctional textiles.

C. We demonstrated that, as expected, the crosslinked crystals are highly biocompatible (ACS Biomater. Sci. Eng.). Biocompatibility opens the door for subsequent applications in biosensing and drug delivery.

Broader Impact. This project consisted of a diverse set of scientific goals, and thus supported a diverse set of graduate and undergraduate researchers. In particular, three successful doctoral degree recepients in the last calendar year contributed to this project, along with a new Ph.D. student who took up the reins this last year. Of the recent graduates, one has obtained a prestigious postdoctoral fellowship at the Protein Design Institute, and two found industry positions without delay. Several undergraduate researchers also contributed to the project, including two senior honors thesis contributions. Several of these students now have industry positions for which they credit their research experience. High school interns were also provided with summer research experiences. Finally, the PI served as the faculty advisor for a new Colorado State University undergraduate organization, formed to compete in BIOMOD, the international biomolecular design competition.


Last Modified: 12/30/2018
Modified by: Christopher D Snow

  • Figure 1. Crosslinked porous crystals are quite stable. Here we show crystals after 2 minutes in:(a) H2O, (b) 100% acetone, (c) 100% DMSO, (d) 100 degrees Celcius H2O, (e) aqua regia, a 3:1 v/v mixture of HCl and HNO3, and (f) pH 11 NaOH buffer.
    Ann Kowalski
    Christopher D Snow
    Figure 1. Stability of crosslinked porous protein crystals
